cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 170, Number 48 (Tuesday, March 19, 2024)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Ms. LOFGREN:H.R. 7724.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article 1, Section 8, Clause 4 provides Congress with thepower to establish a ``uniform rule of Naturalization.''The single subject of this legislation is.To establish under article I of the Constitution of theUnited States, a court of record to be known as the UnitedStates Immigration Courts.[Page H1235]

item.text: Referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and in addition to the Committee on the Budget, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned.

Referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and in addition to the Committee on the Budget, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned.

bill.title: Real Courts, Rule of Law Act of 2024

item.title: Real Courts, Rule of Law Act of 2024
Real Courts, Rule of Law Act of 2024
To establish, under article I of the Constitution of the United States, a court of record to be known as the United States Immigration Courts.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and in addition to the Committee on the Budget, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
